(2) The value of the sign. (3) The street address of the property upon which the sign is to be located and the location of the sign on the property. (4) The square feet area of the sign and the aggregate square foot area. (5) The names and addresses of the owners of the real property upon which the subject sign is to be located. The written consent of the owner must be attached. (6) A sketch or print showing all pertinent information to ensure compliance with this division. (Ord. of 6-17-2004, § 2) Sec. 33-4. - Fees. (a) No sign permit shall be issued until the application has been filed with the clerk and appropriate fees paid. (b) Said permit fees shall be established by the city council and posted in the office of the clerk. (c) A sticker shall be issued and said sticker shall be attached to the sign. (Ord. of 6-17-2004, § 3) Sec. 33-5. - Prohibited signs. The following signs are prohibited: (1) Signs placed on trees, rocks, and utility poles. (2) Signs that obstruct free and clear vision of a street, intersection, or ingress or egress from parking lots. (3) Signs which may interfere with, obstruct the view of or be confused with traffic signs or other warning signs. (Ord. of 6-17-2004, § 4) Sec. 33-6. - Exempt signs. The following signs are exempt from the requirements of this chapter: (1) Non-illuminated real estate signs not in excess of eight square feet, provided such signs are located on the land or building for sale, lease or being constructed. Said sign cannot be on any public right-of-way and are limited to one sign per street frontage. Such signs shall be removed within ten days after the subject property is sold, leased or the construction is completed. (2) Any signs of a non-commercial nature and in the public interest; including public notices, safety signs, danger signs, property streets, and signs of historical interest. (3) Signs on private property directing traffic movement. (4) On-premises signs, provided such signs do not exceed six square feet in area. Such signs shall be limited to one per street front. (5) Any sign that is not visible from public thorough fares or any sign within a business, office or other enclosed area. (6) On-premises "no trespassing," "no hunting" and similar type public notice signs less than four square feet in area. (7) Signs or vending machines which relate to their intended use. (8) Restaurant menu signs and gas pump signs if on private property. (9) Special event signs for non-profit activities as approved by the city. (10) Yard sale signs not to exceed four feet square as long as they are not on a public right-of-way. Such signs shall be removed within three days of the sale. (11) Permanent signs identifying only the name of a residential development. (12) Signs which identify schools, churches, public buildings, non-profit recreation facilities, and public buildings and facilities. (Ord. of 6-17-2004, § 5) Sec. 33-7. - Off-premises freestanding signs. (a) No off-premises sign shall be permitted within a linear distance of 1,000 feet from the nearest point of any other off-premises sign structure, with each side of the road measured independently. (b) No off-premises sign shall be allowed within an historic district. (c) No off-premises sign shall be erected within ten feet of any street right-of-way. (d) The off-premises sign structure shall have a maximum height of 40 feet and a maximum width of 12 feet. (e) No off-premises sign shall be erected within 1,000 feet from a residential structure. (Ord. of 6-17-2004, § 6) Sec. 33-8. - On-premises freestanding signs. (a) No on-premises freestanding sign shall be erected within ten feet of any street right-of-way, provided however, this setback requirement may be reduced to three feet where the road right-of-way is 100 feet or more in width. (b) Two signs per property shall be allowed. (c) The on-premises freestanding sign structure shall have a maximum height of 20 feet. (d) No on-premises sign shall be more than four feet by eight feet in size. (Ord. of 6-17-2004, § 7) Sec. 33-9. - Wall signs. Wall signs shall not project more than 18 inches from the wall face upon which they are attached or situated. (Ord. of 6-17-2004, § 8) Sec. 33-10. - Temporary signs. (a) The owner, or his agent, must notify the city prior to the placement of a temporary sign for special events, grand openings, final closing and so forth. Such permission may be granted up to 30 days per year for the same business. (b) Non-profit activities are exempt from this requirement. (c) The setbacks heretofore noted shall also apply to temporary signs. (Ord. of 6-17-2004, § 9) Sec. 33-11. - Maintenance and appearance signs. (a) All signs shall be maintained in good condition as to present a neat and orderly appearance. The city may cause to be removed, after due notice, any sign which shows gross neglect or becomes dilapidated. The owner will be given 30 days written notice to correct the deficiencies or to remove the sign. If the owner refuses, then the city may have the sign removed at the expense of the owner of the sign or property. (b) The light from any illuminated sign shall not be of an intensity or brightness which may interfere with the general welfare of residents or occupants of adjacent properties. (Ord. of 6-17-2004, § 10) Sec. 33-12. - Political signs. Political signs shall be permitted within the city subject to the following restrictions: (1) Political signs shall not exceed six square feet, unless displaced on a billboard as regulated under off-premises freestanding signs. (2) A political sign shall not be erected more than 90 days prior to the election which the sign is intended to influence; provided however, that the nominee determined in a primary election shall not be required to remove the sign pending the determination of the general election. (3) Any political sign shall be removed within five days after the final election. (4) Political signs must be set back a minimum of ten feet from any public right-of-way. Signs shall not be attached to any street sign, any sign directing or controlling traffic, any utility pole or post, or to any tree, shrub or plant. (5) Before any sign is erected, the permission of the owner or leasee of the property must be obtained. (6) The signs will conform to the other requirements contained in this chapter as to set back and construction. (Ord. of 6-17-2004, § 11) Sec. 33-13. - Existing non-conforming signs. (a) Any permanent sign lawfully existing on the effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived, which does not conform to the provisions of this chapter, may be continued in operation subject to the requirement to maintain as set forth earlier. (b) In the event a sign is destroyed or damaged, then the replaced or rebuilt sign shall conform to the provisions of this chapter. (c) If a business ceases operation, then the owner shall immediately remove all signs, unless there is to be a new operation on the premises within 60 days of closing. (Ord. of 6-17-2004, § 12) Sec. 33-14. - Enforcement and administration. (a) This chapter shall be enforced by the police department of the city. (b) The city may, at its discretion, allow variances in cases of undue or unnecessary hardship or where community health, safety or general welfare demands it. (Ord. of 6-17-2004, § 13)

div.head: Chapter 34 - SOLID WASTES
div.p:
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 34-1. - Definitions. The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Commercial hauler means any person who collects and/or transports solid waste, for a fee, as a business or as an adjunct to a business. Commercial wastes means all waste byproducts of manufacturing or commercial establishments, cinders, and ashes from commercial boilers, and cardboard and wooden boxes, crates and barrels. Director means the director of the solid waste department of the city, or his authorized representative. Garbage means domestic wastes composed of meat, vegetable and fruit scraps, cans, bottles, paper, cardboard, rags, ashes, and other such waste matter normally to be disposed of from residences, churches, schools, small business establishments, and similar places. Animal, fowl, and fish entrails, bones and carcasses, whether in whole or in part, from business establishments such as slaughterhouses and meat and fish markets shall not be considered as garbage, but as other wastes. Litter means and includes garbage, trash, commercial wastes, and other wastes which are scattered about or accumulated in an untidy manner. Litter also means any act which constitutes a violation of section 34-4. Other wastes means animal, fowl, and fish excrement, entrails, bones, carcasses, in whole or in part, and dead animals. Scavenger means any person who salvages or collects, for resale or use, any garbage, paper, cardboard boxes, crates, or other wastes which are being or are to be disposed of from any residence or establishment where people reside, congregate, or are employed. Solid waste means and includes garbage, trash, litter, stumps, tires, or other waste, or combination thereof. Stump means the lower portion of the trunk of a tree or shrub, eight inches in diameter or larger and including portions of the root system. Tire means any tire or tire carcass that has not been shredded or cut into portions less than one-fourth its original size. Trash means and includes yard wastes resulting from normal yard maintenance, such as weeds, grass, and hedge trimmings, leaves, brush, pine straw, tree limbs, and similar items. (Ord. No. 220, § I, 8-18-1987; Ord. of 8-1-2016, § 34-1) Sec. 34-2. - Enforcement. The code enforcement officer shall be the responsible enforcement agency for gaining compliance with this chapter including coordination of warnings or notices of violations. Notices issued shall specify a reasonable time limit for compliance. (Ord. No. 220, § II(c), 8-18-1987; Ord. of 8-1-2016, § 34-2) Sec. 34-3. - Penalty for violation. (a) Any person found to be violating the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of an offense and be in violation of this chapter and shall become liable to the city for any expense, loss, damages, and attorney fees caused by such violation. (b) Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine of not less than $100.00 nor more than $1,000.00; and/or serve not less than ten days nor more than 90 days; or be sentenced to work on the streets of the city, not to exceed three months; or any one or more, or any part of any one or more, of such punishments, in the discretion of the municipal judge or any officer authorized under the City Charter to try the offender. Each day a person fails to comply with the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed a separate offense. Any person in violation of this chapter shall be tried in city court or such other court that may have jurisdiction. This shall apply to non-payment of bills as well as other provisions of this chapter. (Ord. No. 220, § XXVIII, 8-18-1987; Ord. of 8-1-2016, § 34-3) Sec. 34-4. - Unlawful deposit of litter. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person, in person or by his or its agent, employee, or servant, to cast, throw, sweep, sift, or deposit in any manner, or permit to fall or be cast, in or upon any public way or other public place in the city, any kind of garbage, trash, dirt, rubbish, litter, concrete, rocks, stagnant water, dead animals or parts thereof, or waste article, thing, or substance whatsoever, whether liquid or solid. (b) It shall also be unlawful for any person, or by his or its agent, employee or servant, to cast, throw, sweep, sift, deposit in any manner, or permit to fall or be cast any kind of garbage, trash, dirt, rubbish, litter, waste article, thing, or substance whatsoever, whether liquid or solid, anywhere within the city, in such a manner that it may be carried or deposited in whole or in part by any action of the sun, wind, rain, snow, water, animal, or any other such force into any public way or other public place in the city, or into any stream, lake, public water, drain, sewer, or receiving basin. (c) Subsections (a) and (b) of this section shall not apply to the deposit of material under a permit authorized by any ordinance of the city; or to goods, wares, or merchandise deposited upon any public way or public place temporarily, in the necessary course of trade, and removed there from within two hours after being so deposited; or to articles or things deposited in or conducted into the city sewer system through lawful drains, in accordance with the ordinances of the city relating thereto. (d) It shall be unlawful for any person to litter the public streets, sidewalks, or alleys of the city in any manner. (Ord. No. 220, § XXVII, 8-18-1987; Ord. of 8-1-2016, § 34-4) Sec. 34-5. - Unlawful burning. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, permit, allow or suffer any open burning of vegetative matter, to include but not limited to leaves, grasses, tree limbs or stumps, including the slash burning of forest residue from land clearing purposes; of refuse, trash or rubbish of any kind; of any materials which includes soils or are in contact with soils during burning; of any other open burning material; or to use for open burning any non-containment devices such as air-curtain destructors, common back yard fireplaces, open metal drums, burn barrels or burn pits without the prior written consent of the city, and the issuance of a permit except as follows: (1) When a sudden emergency requires a firing in order to render one's premises safe. (2) Fires set for purposes of training firefighting personnel when authorized by the city, said fires to be under the supervision of the chief or his designee. (3) For recreation purposes or cooking food for immediate consumption. (4) Operation of devises using direct flames such as tar kettles, blow torches, welding torches and portable heaters to keep warm for outside working or recreation, and other flame making equipment. (5) Carrying out recognized agricultural procedures necessary for production or harvesting crops. (b) A permit to burn will be issued by the Georgia Forestry Commission (GFC), and any burn shall follow GFC rules and regulations. (Ord. No. 220, § V(6), 8-18-1987; Ord. of 8-1-2016, § 34-5) Secs. 34-6—34-40. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - DIRECTOR
Sec. 34-41. - Appointment. The city council hereby provides for the appointment of a director of the city solid waste department. The director shall be appointed by the mayor, and such appointment shall be approved by the city council. (Ord. No. 220, § II(a), 8-18-1987; Ord. of 8-1-2016, § 34-41) Sec. 34-42. - Duties. The duties of the director shall be to: (1) Supervise the collection of garbage; (2) Supervise garbage collection personnel; (3) Establish collection schedules in accordance with the provisions of this chapter; (4) Supervise the operation of the sanitary landfill and trash burning sites to the satisfaction of the mayor and his duly authorized representative; and (5) Otherwise enforce the terms of this chapter. (Ord. No. 220, § II(b), 8-18-1987; Ord. of 8-1-2016, § 34-42) Sec. 34-43. - Compensation. The city council shall fix the amount of compensation for the director at the time the annual budget is prepared or at the time the city established a position for the director. The city council may, at its discretion, elect to not fund this position until such time that a true need for this position is established. Under this condition, the mayor may designate any official or employee of the city as the director, including himself. (Ord. No. 220, § II(d), 8-18-1987; Ord. of 8-1-2016, § 34-43) Secs. 34-44—34-70. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - CONTAINERS
Sec. 34-71. - Required; capacity; rules. (a) In June 2009, the city purchased 96 gallon containers to allow for larger quantities of waste. Effective August 1, 2009 garbage pickup will be weekly. Only containers furnished by the city are to be utilized. (b) The containers are to be used for household waste only. No paint cans, metals, hazardous waste, grills and any other materials that could damage the containers shall be placed therein. The customers shall use reasonable care to protect and preserve the containers and not expose them to any risk of damage. Any refuse placed in a container shall be bagged. Loose, un-bagged refuse is not to be placed in any container. (c) Any customer consistently accumulating more refuse within a seven-day period than one container can accommodate shall be required to acquire additional containers. All refuse must be placed in a container. (d) The customers shall use reasonable care to protect and preserve the containers and not expose them to any risk of damage. Citizens will be held responsible for any costs for damages or container replacement. (Ord. No. 220, § III, 8-18-1987; Ord. of 8-1-2016, § 34-71) Sec. 34-72. - Commercial establishments. Commercial establishments may provide boxes or bins at the rear thereof for the deposit of wastepaper, boxes, crates, and commercial wastes; but in no event shall stacks or piles of such waste or any containers provided therefore be permitted to obstruct drains, sidewalks, alleys, or streets. The location, construction, and operation of such containers shall meet the approval of the director. (Ord. No. 220, § IV, 8-18-1987; Ord. of 8-1-2016, § 34-72) Sec. 34-73. - Commercial dumpsters. (a) Approval for the use of manufactured containers for emptying by mechanical equipment shall be obtained from the director. (b) The occupants of commercial establishments and the management of multiple dwellings serviced by commercial containers shall be responsible for maintaining the area surrounding such commercial containers clean and free of accumulations of refuse. (c) The following items shall not be disposed of in commercial containers: (1) Household or industrial appliances. (2) Furniture. (3) Tires. (4) Wooden crates. (5) Logs or limbs. (6) Bedsprings. (7) Rock, dirt, or concrete block and bricks. (8) Liquid or any type not in a sealed container. (9) Wet garbage not in a plastic or waterproof bag. (10) Yard debris or household trash not in a cloth, plastic, or paper bag securely sealed. (Ord. No. 220, § XXV, 8-18-1987; Ord. of 8-1-2016, § 34-73) Sec. 34-74. - Placement for collection; removal. (a) All customers shall place the containers in the location established by the city at the time established by the city. The containers shall be moved from the street by the customer no later than 24 hours after trash is collected. (b) Unless an alternate location for collection, due to special circumstances, has been authorized by the director, the city will not collect from any alley or any other location except as set forth herein. (Ord. No. 220, § VI, 8-18-1987; Ord. of 8-1-2016, § 34-74) Sec. 34-75. - Placement of garbage in unauthorized containers. It shall be unlawful to place garbage for collection in a box, tub, crate, or any other container, except one meeting the required specifications of this article. (Ord. No. 220, § V(1), 8-18-1987; Ord. of 8-1-2016, § 34-75) Sec. 34-76. - Use of another person's container prohibited. It shall be unlawful to place garbage, trash, litter, or other waste for collection in a container owned by another person. (Ord. No. 220, § V(5), 8-18-1987; Ord. of 8-1-2016, § 34-76) Sec. 34-77. - Obstruction of department vehicles to prevent access to receptacles. It shall be unlawful for any person to park, permit to park, or leave for any length of time any truck, car, or other vehicle, or to place any obstruction whatsoever, to prevent or hinder the solid waste department vehicles from having free access to any of the solid waste receptacles. (Ord. No. 220, § XXVI, 8-18-1987; Ord. of 8-1-2016, § 34-77) Sec. 34-78. - Obstruction of drains and public ways by commercial wastes. It shall be unlawful to permit stacks or piles of commercial wastes to obstruct drains, sidewalks, alleys, or streets. (Ord. No. 220, § V(2), 8-18-1987; Ord. of 8-1-2016, § 34-78) Sec. 34-79. - Garbage spillage. It shall be unlawful to cause or permit to spill, or to cause or permit to remain spilled, any garbage upon any street, sidewalk, or yard in the city. (Ord. No. 220, § V(3), 8-18-1987; Ord. of 8-1-2016, § 34-79) Sec. 34-80. - Accumulation of items subject to wind. It shall be unlawful to cause or permit to accumulate any dust, ashes, trash, garbage, litter, or commercial waste of such a material that it can be blown away by the wind or blown or carried away by any other force, except when in a container which would control and prevent the blowing of such material. (Ord. No. 220, § V(4), 8-18-1987; Ord. of 8-1-2016, § 34-80) Secs. 34-81—34-110. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL
Sec. 34-111. - Schedules. The director shall notify all persons, in writing or otherwise, as to garbage collection schedules or changes in such schedules; and the director's office shall be prepared to furnish information at any time regarding such schedules. (Ord. No. 220, § VII, 8-18-1987; Ord. of 8-1-2016, § 34-111) Sec. 34-112. - Application; manner and location of trash placement; scattering of trash. (a) Trash shall be collected by city garbage trucks on application to the director by persons having such trash. Collections shall be at a time and in a manner prescribed by the director; provided that at no time shall trash be placed in such a manner as to obstruct gutters, drains, walkways, streets, or alleys. (b) It shall be unlawful to scatter or allow to be scattered any trash placed by the street or alley for collection. (Ord. No. 220, § VIII, 8-18-1987; Ord. No. 222, 9-26-1990; Ord. of 8-1-2016, § 34-112) Sec. 34-113. - Disposal of wastes—Commercial. Commercial wastes which cannot be placed in garbage containers, as specified in this chapter, and which amount to more than four such containers at one time shall not be collected for disposal by city garbage trucks, but shall be disposed of in a manner satisfactory to the solid waste director. At the discretion of the director, such commercial wastes as cardboard or wooden boxes, crates and barrels may be collected by the city garbage trucks for disposal if such wastes are flattened and stacked or knocked down and bundled; and such stacks and bundles shall not exceed four feet in length by three feet in width, nor weigh more than 50 pounds; and not more than 400 pounds of such waste shall be placed for collection at any one time without express permission from the director. (Ord. No. 220, § IX, 8-18-1987; Ord. of 8-1-2016, § 34-113) Sec. 34-114. - Disposal of wastes—Other. Other wastes shall be disposed of by persons in charge of the residence or establishment where such wastes are created or occur. Disposal shall be at the city landfill or as otherwise authorized by the director. (Ord. No. 220, § X, 8-18-1987; Ord. of 8-1-2016, § 34-114) Sec. 34-115. - Disposal of wastes—Medical. It shall be unlawful for any person to dispose of any soiled lint, cotton, or bandages, or waste or refuse of any character whatsoever, from any hospital, sanitarium, infirmary, clinic, or undertakers' shops, whether public or private, in any manner except by incineration. Kitchen wastes from such establishments are expressly exempt from this requirement. (Ord. No. 220, § XI, 8-18-1987; Ord. of 8-1-2016, § 34-115) Sec. 34-116. - Disposal locations. Every person who disposes of any garbage, trash, or commercial or other wastes, whether required to do so by this article or otherwise, shall make such disposal at the city landfill, trash burning sites, or otherwise as specified by the director. (Ord. No. 220, § XII, 8-18-1987; Ord. of 8-1-2016, § 34-116) Sec. 34-117. - Dead animals. Dead animals, excluding livestock, shall be collected by the solid waste department when placed by the streets or alleys separate from other trash. (Ord. No. 220, § XVII, 8-18-1987; Ord. of 8-1-2016, § 34-117) Sec. 34-118. - Old furniture and appliances. Deleted by amendment approved on November 19, 2009. (Ord. No. 220, § XVI, 8-18-1987; Ord. of 8-1-2016, § 34-118) Sec. 34-119. - Rocks, dirt, blocks, and bricks. Rocks, dirt, concrete blocks, or bricks are not considered trash and shall not be collected by the solid waste department. (Ord. No. 220, § XVIII, 8-18-1987; Ord. of 8-1-2016, § 34-119) Sec. 34-120. - Unscheduled collection of certain trash. (a) The city will not collect the following items under any circumstances: (1) Any trash, waste or materials of a commercial business or contractor. (2) No motor vehicles or automotive parts, including tires. (3) No hazardous waste. (4) No refrigerators, air conditioners, HVAC units, or any other appliances or units that may contain Freon or other hazardous materials. (5) No computers, TVs, DVDs or similar units. (6) Any materials or items that could pose a risk to the city's equipment or personnel. (7) Items weighing more than 100 pounds or items classified as bulky and hard to handle. This includes but is not limited to large items of furniture, appliances, hot water heaters, commodes, bathtubs, cabinets, etc. (b) Items weighing less than 100 pounds which are not classified as bulky or hard to handle are subject to the following provisions: (1) These items can be picked up on request at the city for a cost of $15.00 per item or such other fee as may be set by the council. (2) Examples of such items are crates, bicycles, end tables, chairs, push lawn mowers, outside grills and similar items. (3) Exceptions. The city does recognize that special circumstances may exist, such as senior citizens, living on a fixed income, citizens who are disabled and unable to remove the materials themselves due to their disability, therefore, the mayor may consider these factors and reduce or waive fees under the following provisions and exceptions: a. All senior citizens 55 years or older who are not working and live on a fixed income may receive a credit up to 50 percent per item to be picked up. b. Those persons who are disabled who are the head of the household and are disabled under the conditions of the Americans with Disabilities Act and are unable to remove the items themselves and a payment of any fee would create a hardship shall have the fee reduced or eliminated as determined by the mayor. c. Any other unusual or special circumstances may be considered by the mayor on a case by case basis. (4) The resident must take a written request to City Hall and pay the fee for the pickup and obtain a sticker for each item and affix same to the item(s). (5) The pickup will be scheduled for a date and time. (6) The resident will be responsible for placing the items at the location nearest the street as directed by the solid waste department. (c) The city will provide for the removal of leaves, limbs and brush, at no cost to the citizens, on a periodic basis, provided that the materials are not the product of a commercial nature; said materials are placed near the street as directed by the city; and do not obstruct the flow of traffic, cover any drains or pose a risk of any nature to persons or property. Said limbs and brush shall not exceed six inches in diameter and exceed six feet in length. (Ord. No. 220, § XXII, 8-18-1987; Ord. of 8-1-2016, § 34-120) Secs. 34-121—34-150. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - FEES, RATES AND CHARGES
Sec. 34-151. - Applicant requirements. (a) All citizens shall use the city's garbage service and no private garbage service shall pickup refuse in the city unless the refuse is of a nature or quality that the city is unable to provide the service. (b) A citizen can dispose of their own refuse, if done in compliance with the law, but will still be liable to pay the city for the service. (c) Upon moving into the Aragon City Limits, either by buying or renting, a citizen must go to the city clerk's office and fill out a solid waste agreement application, pay a two-month service deposit, and provide photo ID. In addition, if the citizen making application is the owner of the property, the city will require proof of ownership by either warranty deed, quit-claim deed or settlement statement. If the citizen making application is a tenant of the property, the citizens shall provide a copy of a written lease agreement to the city. A work order will then be issued for container delivery. There is an extra cost for a second container. (Ord. of 8-1-2016, § 34-151) Sec. 34-152. - Monthly, yearly rate schedules; street lighting fee. The monthly and/or yearly rate schedule for collection of garbage, commercial wastes, and trash within the city shall be established by the mayor and city council. Each household, residence, and business establishment shall be billed by the city clerk according to these schedules. The mayor and council shall also establish a fee for the lighting of the streets within the city, and this fee will be added to the monthly and/or yearly solid waste bills. (Ord. No. 220, § XX, 8-18-1987; Ord. of 8-1-2016, § 34-152) Sec. 34-153. - Commercial refuse collection; purchase of operational license. The commercial refuse collection fees shall be established by the mayor and council of the city. All commercial haulers operating within the city shall have purchased a license to conduct such business. (Ord. No. 220, § XXIII, 8-18-1987; Ord. of 8-1-2016, § 34-153) Sec. 34-154. - Tax-exempt entities. The monthly or yearly service charge for garbage, trash, or commercial collection service for tax-exempt entities shall be established by the mayor and council. Tax-exempt entities shall not be entitled to receive the free pickup service set out therein. (Ord. No. 220, § XXIV, 8-18-1987; Ord. of 8-1-2016, § 34-154) Sec. 34-155. - Deposit for new residents. Any new residents of the city shall pay a two-month deposit, as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the city clerk. (Ord. No. 221, 11-21-1988; Ord. of 8-1-2016, § 34-155) Sec. 34-156. - Penalty for late payment; discontinuance of service for non-payments; lien. (a) If any fee payable under this article is not paid on the due date as shown on bills submitted to the customer, a penalty of ten percent of the amount due shall be added and collected. (b) If any payment payable thereunder shall remain unpaid for 30 days after the due date, all the customer's refuse service shall be cut off and container retrieved until full payment and a re-delivery fee of $15.00 is made. (c) If a tenant owes a solid waste bill and vacates the property, the city may not place a lien against the owner of the property. But, if a tenant owes a solid waste bill and vacates the property, the city may place a lien against the tenant. The lien shall be issued in the amount of the balance owing plus any penalties or cost of containers which may be missing. (d) If any amount payable thereunder remains past due and unpaid for more than 30 days after service has been discontinued, an execution shall be issued for the collection of such amount. After issuance of such execution, indebtedness shall bear interest at the rate of ten percent per annum on both the original amount and the penalty amounts. Executions shall be made through the city municipal court, or shall be issued for collection of such amount in the manner in which tax executions for the city are issued; and such executions shall be a lien upon all property of the debtor from the date such execution is recorded in the general execution docket of the county superior court. All costs incurred on behalf of the city shall be included in the execution. (Ord. No. 220, § XXI, 8-18-1987; Ord. of 8-1-2016, § 34-156) Secs. 34-157—34-190. - Reserved. ARTICLE VI. - SCAVENGERS
Sec. 34-191. - License—Required. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate as a scavenger within the city who does not possess an occupation tax license secured from the city clerk. (Ord. No. 220, § XIII, 8-18-1987; Ord. of 8-1-2016, § 34-191) Sec. 34-192. - License—Revocation. Violation of the requirement of section 34-194 shall be sufficient cause for immediate revocation of the scavenger license. (Ord. No. 220, § XIV, 8-18-1987; Ord. of 8-1-2016, § 34-192) Sec. 34-193. - License—Reinstatement. A license issued under this article which has been revoked shall not be reinstated or reissued for at least one year from date of revocation. (Ord. No. 220, § XIV, 8-18-1987; Ord. of 8-1-2016, § 34-193) Sec. 34-194. - Manner of operation. Every scavenger shall conduct his operations in such a manner as not to hinder or interfere with the garbage and trash collections and disposal of such by city garbage trucks. Trash, wastes, and garbage shall not be scattered by the scavenger at the place of collection or upon any street, alley, or walkway in the city; nor shall such trash, waste or garbage be left by the scavenger in such a condition that it may be scattered by other persons, animals, or natural causes; and all scavenger trucks shall have a cover approved by the director. (Ord. No. 220, § XV, 8-18-1987; Ord. of 8-1-2016, § 34-194)

div.head: Chapter 38 - TAXATION[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Any ordinance or resolution promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the city or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the city or any evidence of the city's indebtedness saved from repeal, § 1-6(2); any ordinance providing for local improvements and assessing taxes for such improvements saved from repeal, § 1-6(9); any ordinance levying or imposing taxes not included in this Code saved from repeal, § 1-6(14); administration, ch. 2.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 38-1—38-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - OCCUPATIONAL TAXES
Sec. 38-31. - Purpose and scope of article. The occupation tax levied in this article is for revenue purposes only and is not for regulatory purposes; nor is the payment of the tax made a condition precedent to the practice of any such profession, trade, or calling. The occupation tax only applies to those businesses and occupations which are covered by the provisions of O.C.G.A. §§ 48-13-5—48-13-26. All other applicable businesses and occupations are taxed by the local government pursuant to the pertinent general and/or local law and ordinance. (Ord. No. 231, § 8-231.10, 12-19-1994) Sec. 38-32. - Definitions. The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Administrative fee means a component of an occupation tax which approximates the reasonable cost of handling and processing the occupation tax. Dominant line means the type of business, within a multiple-line business, that the greatest amount of income is derived from. Employee means any person, whether owner, family member, regular worker, or part-time worker, who accumulates 40 hours of work time per week at a particular business location. Part-time employees shall be computed on a 40-hour basis. For example, two part-time employees with 20 hours apiece shall be computed as one employee for the purpose of this article. Four employees with 30 hours each shall be computed as three employees (four employees at 30 hours equals a total of 120 hours divided by 40 hours equals three equivalent employees). Gross receipts : (1) The term "gross receipts" means the total revenue of the business or practitioner for the period, including, without limitation, the following: a. Total income without deduction for the cost of goods or expenses incurred; b. Gain from trading in stocks, bonds, capital assets, or instruments of indebtedness; c. Proceeds from commissions on the sale of property, goods, or services; d. Proceeds from fees for services rendered; and e. Proceeds from rent, interest, royalty, or dividend income. (2) The term "gross receipts" shall not include the following: a. Sales, use, or excise tax. b. Sales returns, allowances, and discounts. c. Interorganizational sales or transfers between or among the units of a parent-subsidiary controlled group of corporations, as defined by 26 USC § 1563(a)(1), or between or among the units of a brother-sister controlled group of corporations, as defined by 26 USC § 1563(a)(2). d. Payments made to a subcontractor or an independent agent. e. Governmental and foundation grants, charitable contributions, or the interest income derived from such funds received by a nonprofit organization which employs salaried practitioners otherwise covered by this article, if such funds constitute 100 percent or more of the organization's receipts. Location of office does not include a temporary work site which serves a single customer or project. Occupation tax means a tax levied on persons, partnerships, corporations, or other entities for engaging in an occupation, profession, or business for revenue-raising purposes. Person means and includes sole proprietors, corporations, partnerships, nonprofits, or any other form of business organization, but specifically excludes charitable nonprofit organizations which utilize 100 percent of their proceeds for charitable purposes. Practitioner of profession and occupation means one who, by state law, requires state licensure regulating such profession or occupation. This term shall not include a practitioner who is an employee of a business, if the business pays an occupation tax. Regulatory fees means payments, whether designated as license fees, permit fees, or by another name, which are required by a local government as an exercise of its police power and as a part of or an aid to regulation of an occupation, profession, or business. The amount of a regulatory fee shall approximate the reasonable cost of the actual regulatory activity performed by the city. A regulatory fee may not include an administrative fee. Development impact fees, as defined by O.C.G.A. § 36-71-2(8), or other costs or conditions of zoning or land development are not regulatory fees. (Ord. No. 231, § 8-231, 12-19-1994) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 38-33. - Enforcement. It is hereby made the duty of the city clerk and police department to see that the provisions of this article relating to occupation taxes are observed; and to summon all violators of this article to appear before the municipal court. It is hereby made the further duty of the police chief and his assistants to inspect all registrations issued by the city as often as, in their judgment, it may seem necessary to determine whether the registration held is the proper one for the business sought to be transacted thereunder. (Ord. No. 231, § 8-231.29, 12-19-1994) Sec. 38-34. - Penalty for violation of article provisions. Any person violating any provision of this article shall, upon conviction before the city or county judge, be fined in an amount not exceeding $500.00 or imprisoned for a period not exceeding 360 days at the discretion of the municipal court judge. (Ord. No. 231, § 8-231.17, 12-19-1994) Sec. 38-35. - Subpoena and arrest powers. The city police chief and his duly designated officer shall be empowered with full subpoena and arrest powers in conjunction with any violation pertaining to this article. (Ord. No. 231, § 8-231.18, 12-19-1994) Sec. 38-36. - Payment of annual tax required. Each person engaged in any business, trade, profession, or occupation in the city, whether with a location in the city or, in the case of an out-of-state business with no location in the state exerting substantial efforts within the state pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-7, shall pay an annual occupation tax for such business, trade, profession, or occupation; which tax and any applicable registration shall be displayed in a conspicuous place in the place of business, if the taxpayer has a permanent business location in the city. If the taxpayer has no permanent business location in the city, such business tax registration shall be shown to the city clerk or his deputies, or to any police officer of the city, upon request. (Ord. No. 231, § 8-231.1, 12-19-1994) Sec. 38-37. - Administrative and regulatory fees. (a) A nonprorated, nonrefundable administrative fee, as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the city clerk, shall be required on all business and occupation tax accounts for the initial startup, renewal, or reopening of those accounts. (b) A regulatory fee will be imposed, as provided under O.C.G.A. § 48-13-9, on those applicable businesses. A regulatory fee may not include an administrative fee. (c) The regulatory fee schedule for persons in occupations and professions requiring a regulatory fee is provided for in section 38-38. (Ord. No. 231, § 8-231.3, 12-19-1994) Sec. 38-38. - Regulatory fee schedule. The regulatory fee imposed by this article shall be as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the city clerk. (Ord. No. 231, § 8-231.35, 12-19-1994) Sec. 38-39. - Levy; tax rate. (a) An occupation tax shall be levied upon those businesses and practitioners of professions and occupations with one or more locations or offices in the city and/or upon the applicable out-of-state businesses with no location or office in this state, pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-7, based upon the number of employees of the business or practitioner. (b) The tax rate determined by the number of employees for each business, trade, profession, or occupation shall be as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the city clerk. (Ord. No. 231, § 8-231.4, 12-19-1994) Sec. 38-40. - Registration and assessment imposed on businesses with no in-state location. Registration and assessment of an occupation tax is hereby imposed on those businesses and practitioners of professions with no location or office in the state, if the business' largest dollar volume of business in the state is in the city and the business or practitioner: (1) Has one or more employees or agents who exert substantial efforts within the jurisdiction of the city for the purpose of soliciting business or serving customers or clients; or (2) Owns personal or real property which generates income and is located within the jurisdiction of the city. (Ord. No. 231, § 8-231.5, 12-19-1994) Sec. 38-41. - Registration required; liability of officers and agents upon failure to obtain. All persons subject to the occupation tax levy pursuant to this article shall be required to obtain the necessary registration for such business as described in this article; and, in default thereof, the officers or agents soliciting for or representing such persons shall be subject to the same penalty as other persons who fail to obtain a registration. Every person commencing business in the city after January 31 of each year shall likewise obtain the registration provided for in this section before commencing business; and any person transacting, or offering to transact, in the city any of the kinds of business, trade, profession, or occupation without first having so obtained such registration shall be subject to penalties provided thereof. (Ord. No. 231, § 8-231.16, 12-19-1994) Sec. 38-42. - Identification of line of business on business registration. The business registration of each business operated in the city shall identify the line or lines of business that the business conducts. No business shall conduct any line of business without first having that line of business registered with the city clerk and that line of business being noted by the city upon the business registration form which is to be displayed by the business owner. (Ord. No. 231, § 8-231.6, 12-19-1994) Sec. 38-43. - Each business location considered separate business. Where a person conducts business at more than one fixed location, each location or place shall be considered a separate business for the purpose of occupation tax. (Ord. No. 231, § 8-231.7, 12-19-1994) Sec. 38-44. - Registration and tax payment required for multiple locations or lines of business. Where a business is operated at more than one location and if the business conducts different business activities, then the business shall be required to obtain the necessary registration for each location having a different business activity and shall also pay the required occupation tax for each location having a different business activity. (Ord. No. 231, § 8-231.22, 12-19-1994) Sec. 38-45. - Evidence of state licensure prior to city registration; display of state license. (a) Each person who is licensed by the secretary of state, pursuant to O.C.G.A. title 43, shall provide evidence of proper and current state licensure before city registration may be issued. (b) Each person who is licensed by the state shall post the state license in a conspicuous place in the licensee's place of business, and shall keep the license there at all times while the license remains valid. (Ord. No. 231, § 8-231.14, 12-19-1994) Sec. 38-46. - Evidence of obtaining required permits, certificates, etc., prior to city registration. Any business required to obtain health permits, bonds, certificates of qualification, certificates of competency, or any other regulatory matter shall first, before the issuance of a city business registration, show evidence that such requirements have been met. (Ord. No. 231, § 8-231.15, 12-19-1994) Sec. 38-47. - Election of tax by practitioners of professions classified by state law. (a) Practitioners of professions as described in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-9(c)(1)—(18) shall elect, as their entire occupation tax, one of the following: (1) The occupation tax based on number of employees, as set forth in section 38-39; or (2) A fee per practitioner, as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the city clerk, such tax to be paid at the practitioner's office or location; provided, however, that a practitioner paying according to this subsection shall not be required to provide information to the local government relating to the gross receipts of the business or practitioner. The per-practitioner fee applies to each person in the business who qualifies as a practitioner under the state's regulatory guidelines and framework. (b) This election is to be made on an annual basis and must be done by January 31 of each year. (Ord. No. 231, § 8-231.8, 12-19-1994) Sec. 38-48. - Establishment and payment of tax by newly established businesses. In the case of a business subject to occupation tax for a calendar year, which was not conducted for any period of time in the city in the preceding year, the owner, proprietor, manager, or executive officer of the business liable for occupation tax shall estimate the number of employees projected for the business and such occupational tax shall be paid for the first year, or partial year, that the business is in operation, based on such estimation, and paid prior to the commencement of the business operation. (Ord. No. 231, § 8-231.21, 12-19-1994) Sec. 38-49. - When tax due and payable; late fees and other penalties for delinquency; collection by police chief. (a) Each occupation tax levied under this article shall be for the calendar year, unless otherwise specifically provided. Such registration and occupation tax shall be payable January 31 of each year and shall, if not paid by March 1 of each year, be subject to a late fee as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the city clerk. If the total amount of the occupation tax and late fees is not paid by April 10, then additional penalties for delinquency shall be assessed as prescribed in this article, the Charter of the city, and/or general state law. On any new profession, trade, or calling begun in the city during a calendar year, the registration and tax shall be delinquent if not obtained immediately upon beginning business, and a penalty as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges shall be imposed. The tax registration provided for in this section shall be issued by the city clerk; and, if any person whose duty it is to obtain a registration shall, after such registration or occupation tax becomes delinquent, transact or offer to transact, in the city, any of the kind of profession, trade, or calling subject to this article without having first obtained such registration, such offender shall, upon conviction by the municipal court judge, be punished by a fine not to exceed $500.00, or imprisonment not to exceed 360 days, either or both in the discretion of the municipal court judge. (b) In addition to the above remedies, the city police chief may proceed to collect in the same manner as provided by general state law for tax executions. (Ord. No. 231, § 8-231.11, 12-19-1994) Sec. 38-50. - Exemptions from payment—Practitioners exclusively practicing for government. Any practitioner whose office is maintained by, and who is employed in practice exclusively by, the United States, the state, a municipality or county of the state, instrumentalities of the United States, the state, or a municipality or county of the state shall not be required to obtain a license or pay an occupation tax for that practice. (Ord. No. 231, § 8-231.9, 12-19-1994) Sec. 38-51. - Exemptions from payment—Tax inapplicable where prohibited or exempted by law. An occupation tax shall not apply to the gross receipts of any part of a business where such levy is prohibited or exempted by state law or laws of the United States. (Ord. No. 231, § 8-231.20, 12-19-1994) Sec. 38-52. - Exemptions from payment—Charitable purpose. No business on which a business registration or occupation tax is levied by this article shall be exempt from such registration or tax on the ground that such business is operated for a charitable purpose, unless 100 percent of the entire proceeds from such business are devoted to such purpose. (Ord. No. 231, § 8-231.13, 12-19-1994) Sec. 38-53. - Businesses not covered by article. The following businesses are not covered by the provisions of this article, but may be assessed an occupation tax or other type of tax pursuant to the provisions of the general laws of the state or by local law: (1) Businesses regulated by the state public service commission. (2) Electrical service businesses under O.C.G.A. title 46, chapter 3. (3) Any farm operation for the production from or on the land of agricultural products, but not including agribusiness. (4) Cooperative marketing associations governed by O.C.G.A. § 2-10-105. (5) Insurance companies governed by O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8 et seq. (6) Motor common carriers governed by O.C.G.A. § 46-7-15. (7) Businesses governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-5-355. (Businesses that purchase carload lots of guano, meats, meal, flour, bran, cottonseed or cottonseed meal and hulls.) (8) Agricultural products and livestock raised in the state governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-5-356. (9) Depository financial institutions governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93. (10) Facilities operated by a charitable trust governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-55. (Ord. No. 231, § 8-231.19, 12-19-1994) Sec. 38-54. - Returns confidential. Except in the case of judicial proceedings or other proceedings necessary to collect the occupation tax hereby levied, it shall be unlawful for any officer, employee, agent, or clerk of the city or any other person to divulge or make known in any manner the amount of gross receipts or any particulars set forth or disclosed in any occupation tax return required under this article. All contents of such return shall be confidential and open only to the officials, employees, agents, or clerks of the city using such returns for the purpose of this occupation tax levy and the collection of the tax. Independent auditors or bookkeepers employed by the city shall be classed as employees. Nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit the publication, by city officials, of statistics, so classified as to prevent the identification of particular reports or returns and items thereof; or the inspection of the records by duly qualified employees of the tax departments of the state, the United States, and other local governments. (Ord. No. 231, § 8-231.23, 12-19-1994) Sec. 38-55. - Inspection of books and records. The city clerk, through his officers, agents, employees, or representatives, may inspect the books of the business for which the returns are made. The city clerk shall have the right to inspect the books or records for the business of which the return was made in the city, and, upon demand of the city clerk, such books or records shall be submitted for inspection by a representative of the city within 30 days. Failure of submission of such books or records within 30 days shall be grounds for revocation of the tax registration currently existing to do business in the city. Adequate records shall be kept in the city for examination by the city clerk at that officer's discretion. If, after examination of the books or records, it is determined that a deficiency occurs as a result of underreporting, a penalty of $25.00 will be assessed for the period delinquent. (Ord. No. 231, § 8-231.24, 12-19-1994) Sec. 38-56. - Revocation of registration for failure to pay tax, file or make true returns, or permit inspection of books. Upon the failure of any business to pay the occupation tax or any part thereof before it becomes delinquent, or upon failure to make any of such returns within the time required in this article, or upon failure to make a true return, or upon failure to amend a return to set forth the truth, or upon failure to permit inspection of its books as provided in section 38-55, any business tax registration granted by the city under this article permitting the owner of such business to do business for the current year shall be, ipso facto, revoked. No new business tax registration shall be granted by the city for the operation of a business for which any part of the occupation tax provided for in this section is at that time unpaid. In the case of those practitioners where the local government cannot suspend the right of the practitioner to conduct business, the imposition of civil penalties shall be permitted and pursued by the local government in the case of delinquent occupation tax. (Ord. No. 231, § 8-231.25, 12-19-1994) Sec. 38-57. - Lien for delinquent tax. In addition to the other remedies provided in this article for the collection of the occupation tax levied in this article, the city clerk, upon any tax or installment of such tax becoming delinquent and remaining unpaid, shall issue execution for the correct amount of such tax against the person liable for such tax, which such execution shall bear interest at the rate of 12 percent per annum from the date when such tax or installment becomes delinquent; and the lien shall cover the property in the city of the person liable for such tax, all as provided by the Charter and ordinances of the city, and state law. The lien of such occupation tax shall become fixed on and dated from the time when such tax or any installment thereof becomes delinquent. The execution shall be levied by the police chief or his representative upon the property of the defendant located in such jurisdiction; and sufficient property shall be advertised and sold to pay the amount of such execution, with interest and costs. All other proceedings in relation thereto shall be had as is provided by the Charter and ordinances of the city, and state law; and the defendant in such execution shall have rights of defense, by affidavit of illegality and otherwise, which are provided by the applicable laws in regard to tax executions. When a nulla bona entry has been entered by proper authority upon an execution issued by the city against any person defaulting on the occupation tax, the person against whom the entry was made shall not be allowed or entitled to have or collect any fees or charges whatsoever for services rendered after the entry of the nulla bona. If, at any time after the entry of nulla bona has been made, the person against whom the execution issues pays the tax in full, together with all interest and costs accrued on the tax, the person may collect any fees and charges due him as though he had never defaulted in the payment of the taxes. (Ord. No. 231, § 8-231.26, 12-19-1994) Sec. 38-58. - Amendment or repeal; preservation of city rights; increase or decrease in tax rates. This article shall be subject to amendment or repeal, in whole or in part, at any time; and no such amendment or repeal shall be construed to deny the right of the mayor and council to assess and collect any of the taxes or other charges prescribed. Such amendment may increase or lower the amounts and tax rates of any occupation and may change the classification thereof. The payment of any occupation tax provided for shall not be construed as prohibiting the levy or collection by the jurisdiction of additional occupation taxes upon the same person, property, or business. (Ord. No. 231, § 8-231.27, 12-19-1994) Sec. 38-59. - Public hearing before tax increase. The mayor and council shall conduct at least one public hearing before adopting any ordinance or resolution which will increase the rate of occupation tax as set forth in this article. (Ord. No. 231, § 8-231.30, 12-19-1994) Sec. 38-60. - Exemption or reduction in tax for economic development or to encourage select types of occupation. The mayor and council may, by subsequent ordinance or resolution, provide for an exemption or reduction in occupation tax to one or more types of businesses or practitioners of occupations or professions as part of a plan for economic development or attracting or encouraging selected types of businesses or practitioners of selected occupations or professions. Such exemptions or reductions in occupation tax shall not be arbitrary or capricious, and the reasons shall be set forth in the minutes of the city. (Ord. No. 231, § 8-231.31, 12-19-1994) Sec. 38-61. - Effect of article on prior ordinances. This article does not repeal or affect the force of any part of any ordinance passed prior to this article, where taxes levied under such prior ordinance have not been paid in full. So much and such parts of ordinances passed prior to and after this article as provided for the issuing and enforcing of execution for any tax or assessment required by such ordinances, or that imposed fines or penalties for the nonpayment of such tax, or for failure to pay regulatory fees provided for in such ordinances or failure to comply with any other provisions hereof, shall continue and remain in force until such tax, regulatory fee, or assessment shall be fully paid. (Ord. No. 231, § 8-231.28, 12-19-1994) Sec. 38-62. - Conflicts between specific and general provisions. Where there is an apparent conflict in this article between specific and general provisions, it is the intention of this article that the specific provision shall control. (Ord. No. 231, § 8-231.31, 12-19-1994) Secs. 38-63—38-90. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - INSURERS[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— General assembly authorized to provide for taxation of insurance companies based on gross direct premiums received from insurance policies within the unincorporated areas of counties, Ga. Const. art. IX, § IV, ¶ (c).
Sec. 38-91. - License fee—Annual levy on companies; additional fee for separate business locations. There is hereby levied an annual license fee, as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges, upon every insurance company engaging in the business of insurance within the corporate limits of the city; and there is hereby levied an additional annual license fee in such amount for each separate business location in excess of one operated and maintained by any such company within the corporate limits. State Law reference— Local tax on life insurance companies, O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.1. Sec. 38-92. - License fee—Additional fee for companies operated by businesses lending money or offering term financing of sales, soliciting insurance applications. There is hereby levied an additional license fee, as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges, on each insurance company for each separate business location not otherwise subject to a license fee under section 38-91, which company is operated and maintained by a business organization which is engaged in the business of lending money or transacting sales involving term financing, and which, in connection with the loans or sales involving term financing, offers, solicits, or takes applications for insurance through a licensed agent of the insurance company for insurance. State Law reference— Local tax on other than life insurance companies, O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.2. Sec. 38-93. - License fee—Annual levy on independent agencies and brokers for separate life insurance business locations. There is hereby levied an annual license fee upon independent agencies and brokers for each separate business location from which a life insurance business is conducted and which is not subject to the company license fee imposed by either section 38-91 or section 38-92, in the amount set forth in the schedule of fees and charges, for each such location within the city. Sec. 38-94. - License fee—Date due and payable. License fees imposed in this article shall be due and payable February 1 of each year. Sec. 38-95. - Gross direct premiums tax—Life, accident, and sickness insurance. There is hereby levied an annual tax based solely upon gross direct premiums upon each insurer writing life, accident, and sickness insurance within the city, in an amount equal to one percent of the gross direct premiums received during the calendar year in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.1. The term "gross direct premiums," as used in this section, shall mean gross direct premiums as used in O.C.G.A. § 33-8-4. The premium tax levied by this section is in addition to the license fees imposed by sections 38-91 and 38-92. Sec. 38-96. - Gross direct premiums tax—Other classes of insurance. There is hereby levied an annual tax upon each insurer, other than an insurer transacting business in the class of insurance designated in O.C.G.A. § 33-3-5(1), doing business as provided in O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.2, in an amount equal to 2½ percent of the gross direct premiums received during the calendar year, in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.2. The term "gross direct premiums," as used in this section, shall mean gross direct premiums as used in O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.2(a). Secs. 38-97—38-130. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS[3]
Footnotes: --- (3) --- State Law reference— Local depository financial institutions business license tax, O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93.
Sec. 38-131. - Definition. The term "gross receipts," as used in this article, has the same meaning as is ascribed to the term "gross receipts" for each such depository financial institution in O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93. Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 38-132. - Levy of annual business license tax. (a) Pursuant to the authority contained in O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93, there is levied for each year, upon each state and national bank, federal savings and loan association, and state building and loan association located in the city, not exempted by state law, an annual business license tax at the rate of 0.25 percent of the gross receipts of each such institution, or $1,000.00, per annum, whichever amount is greater. (b) The tax levied by subsection (a) of this section for each year shall be levied on the amount of gross receipts received by each such depository financial institution during the immediately preceding calendar year. Sec. 38-133. - Return of gross receipts received. Each depository financial institution subject to the tax levied by this article shall file with the city, not later than March 1 of each year, a return of its gross receipts received by it during the immediately preceding calendar year. The return shall be made in the manner and in the form prescribed by the commissioner of the department of banking and shall be based on the allocation method set forth in O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93(d). The tax levied pursuant to this article shall be assessed and collected based upon the information provided in the return. Sec. 38-134. - When tax due and payable. The tax levied by this article shall be due and payable on April 1 of each year.

div.head: Chapter 40 - TELECOMMUNICATIONS
div.p:
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 40-1—40-18. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - DUE COMPENSATION
Sec. 40-19. - Due compensation for telephone companies with end user retail customers within the city. (a) The city hereby requires due compensation of three percent of actual recurring local service revenues, as defined in paragraphs (8) and (9) of subsection (b) of § 46-5-1 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated; provided, however, that any company which pays in excess of three percent of actual recurring local service revenues pursuant to an existing franchise agreement shall continue to pay in accordance with the agreement until the expiration of the franchise agreement or December 31, 2012, whichever occurs first, and any company which pays in excess of three percent of actual recurring local service revenues in accordance with an occupational license tax arrangement shall continue to pay in accordance with such payment schedule until December 31, 2012. (b) Regarding any telephone company that does not have retail, end user customers located within the city's municipal boundaries, the payment by such company to a municipal authority in accordance with the rates set by regulations promulgated by the department of transportation for the use of its rights-of-way shall be considered the payment of due compensation. (Ord. of 6-16-2009(2), § 1) Sec. 40-20. - Authorized designee. The mayor shall, on behalf of the city, exercise day-to-day administrative duties necessary to fulfill the regulatory authority of the city under O.C.G.A. § 46-5-1 et seq. and shall perform the following duties: (1) Review application information submitted by a telephone company to the city and, if an application is incomplete, notify the telegraph or telephone company within 15 business days of the receipt of such application, identifying in such notice all application deficiencies. (2) Report the receipt of a completed application to the council within 60 calendar days of the receipt of such completed application. (3) Review payments of due compensation submitted by the company to ensure compliance with the provisions of the amended law and this article. (4) Provide a coordination function between a telephone company and all city departments on any matter relating to the amended law and this article. (5) Arrange and evaluate, no more than once a year, a comprehensive review of the records of a company which is reasonably related to the calculation and payment of due compensation. (6) Provide to all telegraph and telephone companies located in its right-of-way written notice of annexations and changes in municipal corporate boundaries. (Ord. of 6-16-2009(2), § 2) Secs. 40-21—40-43. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - TELECOMMUNICATIONS FACILITIES
Sec. 40-44. - General requirements for all telecommunications facilities. The requirements set forth in this article shall govern the location and construction of all telecommunications facilities governed by this article. (Ord. of 1-21-2010, § 1) Sec. 40-45. - Building codes and safety standards. To ensure the structural integrity of telecommunications facilities, the owner of a telecommunications facility shall ensure that it is maintained in compliance with standards contained in applicable local building codes and the applicable standards for such telecommunications facilities, as amended from time to time. The owner shall visually inspect each tower on an annual basis and file a written report to the building inspection department with the findings of such inspection. (Ord. of 1-21-2010, § 2) Sec. 40-46. - Regulatory compliance. (a) All telecommunications facilities must meet or exceed current standards and regulations of the FAA, the FCC and any other agency of the state or federal government with the authority to regulate telecommunications facilities. If such standards and regulations are changed then the owners of the telecommunications facilities governed by this article shall bring such telecommunications facilities into compliance with such revised standards and regulations within the time frame established by the agency promulgating the standards or regulations. (b) Owners of telecommunications facilities shall provide documentation showing that each telecommunications facility is in compliance with all applicable federal and state requirements. Evidence of compliance must be submitted every 12 months. Failure to provide such documentation over the course of any five-year period shall constitute evidence of abandonment. (Ord. of 1-21-2010, § 3) Sec. 40-47. - Security. All telecommunications facilities shall be equipped with an appropriate anticlimbing device or other similar protective device to prevent unauthorized access to the telecommunications facility. (Ord. of 1-21-2010, § 4) Sec. 40-48. - Lighting. No illumination is permitted on telecommunication facilities unless required by the FCC, FAA or other state or federal agency of competent jurisdiction or unless necessary for air traffic safety. If lighting is required or necessary, the building official may review the available lighting alternatives and approve the design that would cause the least disturbance to the surrounding uses and views. (Ord. of 1-21-2010, § 5) Sec. 40-49. - Advertising. No advertising is permitted on telecommunications facilities. However, a whip antenna may be allowed on any legally permitted permanent billboard or outdoor advertising sign as long as the other requirements of this article are met. (Ord. of 1-21-2010, § 6) Sec. 40-50. - Visual impact. (a) Telecommunications facilities shall either maintain a galvanized steel finish or, subject to any applicable standards of the FAA or other applicable federal or state agency, be painted a neutral color or painted and/or textured to match the existing structure so as to reduce visual obtrusiveness. (b) If an antenna is installed on a structure other than a tower, the antenna and associated electrical and mechanical equipment must be of a neutral color that is identical to, or closely compatible with, the color of the supporting structure so as to make the antenna and related equipment as visually unobtrusive as possible. Roof-mounted antennas shall be made visually unobtrusive by screening to match existing air conditioning units, stairs, elevator towers or other background. (c) Where feasible, telecommunication facilities should be placed directly above, below or incorporated with vertical design elements of a building to help in camouflaging. (d) Telecommunication facilities shall not be placed in a direct line of sight with historic or scenic view corridors as designated by the governing body or by any state or federal law or agency. (e) Any equipment shelter or cabinet that supports telecommunications facilities must be concealed from public view or made compatible with the architecture of the surrounding, structures or placed underground. Equipment shelters or cabinets shall be screened from public view by using landscaping, or materials and colors consistent with the surrounding backdrop. The shelter or cabinet must be regularly maintained. (Ord. of 1-21-2010, § 7) Sec. 40-51. - Maintenance impacts. Equipment at a transmissions facility shall be automated to the greatest extent possible to reduce traffic and congestion. Where the site abuts or has access to a collector or local street, access for maintenance vehicles shall be exclusively by means of the collector or local street. (Ord. of 1-21-2010, § 8) Sec. 40-52. - Exemptions. The following exemptions to this article shall apply: (1) Any communications tower and antenna under 70 feet in total height which is owned and operated by an amateur radio operator licensed by the Federal Communications Commission; (2) Any device designed for over-the-air reception of television broadcast signals, multichannel multipoint distribution service or direct broadcast satellite service; (3) Any telecommunications facilities located on property owned, leased or otherwise controlled by the city provided a license or lease authorizing the telecommunications facility has been approved by the governing body; or (4) Any cable television headend or hub tower and antennae used solely for cable television services. (Ord. of 1-21-2010, § 9) Sec. 40-53. - Preferred locations. (a) Co-location. The applicant shall make a reasonable attempt to co-locate on existing communications tower, buildings, or other tall structures. The applicant shall be willing to allow other users to co-locate on the proposed communications tower in the future, subject to engineering capabilities of the structure, frequency considerations, and proper compensation from the additional user. Proper compensation shall be determined by the applicant providing an average of the lease rates it pays for co-location sites in Polk County. The rate information shall be deemed a trade secret of the applicant and shall be made available only to the building official who shall not be allowed to disclose it. (b) Stealth or concealed structure. The support structure for an antenna which is primarily for another principal use or accessory to the principal use on the lot where it is located, and partially or wholly conceals the antenna or minimizes its appearance in relation to the principal use of the stealth structure. (c) Existing publicly used facilities, structures and utilities. Publicly used structures are preferred locations throughout the city because they are dispersed throughout the city and due to their institutional or infrastructure uses are generally similar in appearance to or readily adaptable for telecommunications facilities. Therefore, telecommunications facilities should be less noticeable when placed on publicly used structures than when placed on commercial or industrial structures. Publicly-used structures include, but are not limited to, facilities such as police or fire stations, libraries, community centers, civic centers, courthouses, utility structures, water towers, elevated roadways, bridges, flag poles, schools, hospitals, clock or bell towers, light poles and churches. Construction of the telecommunications facility is permitted so long as the telecommunications facility adds no more than 20 feet to the height of said existing structure. (d) Industrial and commercial structures. Wholly industrial and commercial structures such as warehouses, factories, retail outlets, supermarkets, banks, garages, or service stations shall be preferred locations. Construction of the telecommunications facility adds no more than 20 feet to the height of said existing structure. (Ord. of 1-21-2010, § 10) Sec. 40-54. - Maintenance. An annual inspection of the telecommunications facility and its associated site is required. A report of this inspection is to be filed with the building official. (Ord. of 1-21-2010, § 11) Sec. 40-55. - Principal, accessory and joint uses. (a) Accessory structures used in direct support of a telecommunications facility shall be allowed but are not to be used for offices, vehicle storage or other outdoor storage. Mobile or immobile equipment not used in direct support of a telecommunications facility shall not be stored or parked on the site of the telecommunications facility. (b) Telecommunications facilities may be located on sites containing another principal use in the same buildable area. (Ord. of 1-21-2010, § 12) Sec. 40-56. - Zoning, height and setbacks. (a) Zoning. Communication towers may be placed in P-l, C-l and M districts. (b) Height. Communication towers shall not exceed 250 feet in height. (c) Setbacks. The following setback requirements shall apply to all telecommunications facilities: (1) Communication towers shall not be located any closer than 1,500 feet from an existing tower unless technologically required or visually preferable. (2) Communication towers exceeding a height of 125 feet may not be placed within 3,000 feet to each other. (3) Communication towers must be set back from any off-site residential lot a distance equal to the height of the tower. (4) Communication towers, guy wires and accessory facilities must satisfy the minimum setback requirements of the zoning district in which it is located. (5) For antennas attached to the roof or a supporting structure on a rooftop, a 1:1 setback ratio (example: ten-foot high antenna and supporting structure require ten-foot setback from the edge of roof) shall be maintained unless an alternative placement is shown to reduce visual impact. (Ord. of 1-21-2010, § 13(1)) Sec. 40-57. - Additional requirements for towers. (a) Site location and development shall preserve the preexisting character of the surrounding buildings and land uses and the zone district as much as possible. Communication towers shall be integrated through location and design to blend in with the existing characteristics of the site to the extent practical. (b) At a tower site the design of the buildings and related structures shall, to the extent possible, use materials, colors, textures, screening, and landscaping that will blend the tower and related facilities to the natural setting and built environment. (c) Communication towers shall be enclosed by decay-resistant security fencing not less than six feet in height and shall be equipped with an appropriate anti-climbing device or other similar protective device designed to prevent tower access. (Ord. of 1-21-2010, § 13(2)) Sec. 40-58. - Application requirements. (a) General. The person, company or organization that will own or operate the communications facility shall make application for a permit for any communication tower or antenna to the building official. An application will not be considered until it is complete. A special land use permit shall be required for each telecommunications facility to be installed. The following information shall be submitted for each permit request: (b) Basic information. (1) The name, mail address, telephone numbers, facsimile number and electronic mail address, if applicable, of the applicant. (2) The type of personal wireless service to be provided by the communications facility. (3) Site plan or plans to scale specifying the location of communications facilities, transmission building and/or other accessory uses, access, parking, fences, and adjacent land uses. (4) Identification of geographic service area for the subject installation, including a map showing the site and the nearest or associated telecommunications facility sites within the network. Describe the distance between the telecommunications facility sites. Describe how this service area fits into and is necessary for the service network. (5) A full description of the adjacent properties including any residential structures and districts, listed or eligible structures and sites on the National Register of Historic Places, floodplains, wetlands, listed threatened or endangered species or critical habitats, wildlife management areas, protected river corridors and state waters. (6) An elevation landscape drawing or computer-enhanced image showing the antenna and its supporting structure as seen: a. From the closet property line; and b. From the appropriate property line towards the nearest scenic view or site as established in the comprehensive plan of Polk County and the cities of Aragon and Rockmart.
